author: sky.cactus
content: 216 ETH / day is the *minimum* it would cost to maintain this sort of shutdown.  However, people could increase their fee premium to raise that cost very significantly if it was sustained.

author: sky.cactus
content: Once you started the attack, the base fee would quickly drop, and people would would switch over to what is functionally a gas price auction.  At that point that 216 ETH / day quickly turns into 2160 ETH per day (assuming base fee would otherwise be ~10 nanoeth / gas), and likely ramps up more and more over time as people are willing to pay more and more to get included.

author: slodkokwasny.
content: So someone could start submitting empty blocks for 0.05 ETH to MEV relays and keep throttling the network for $70 a block (basically bribing validators), and the only countermeasure is for the users to increase their priority fees. Seems dangerous but maybe it's not really... the cost for throttling is equal to the average priority fees in a block right now, and since we're in a bear market, it's quite low at 0.05 ETH. If activity were to pick up again, it would get a little bit more expensive.

author: jgm
content:
The bribe has to be higher than the sum of all tips that would be made by the proposer if they included the waiting transactions in the block.  That value will increase over time three ways: i) the base fee will drop so type 0 transactions will have a higher tip, ii) users will increase their tips because they want their transactions to go through, and iii) there will be more transactions in the pending pool so more higher-value transactions from which block builders can include in the block.  I don't see it being a particularly viable strategy for anything other than short-term amusement.

(It also requires all proposers to be listening for relayed blocks rather than building their own, which is by no means the case today.)
